articles.headline: After Tragedy, Ballroom Dancers Find Hope in Each Other’s Arms
articles.snippet: The mass shooting in Monterey Park threatened a community of dancers who share a rich history. They’re looking for a way to carry on.
articles.abstract: The mass shooting in Monterey Park threatened a community of dancers who share a rich history. They’re looking for a way to carry on.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Corina Knoll, Isabelle Qian, Ben Laffin and Li Qiang

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Won’t Bring Charges Against Gaetz in Sex-Trafficking Inquiry
articles.snippet: Prosecutors investigated if the Florida congressman had broken federal laws, focusing on allegations involving sex trafficking and sex with a minor.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors investigated if the Florida congressman had broken federal laws, focusing on allegations involving sex trafficking and sex with a minor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has decided not to bring charges against Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, after a lengthy sex-trafficking investigation that imperiled one of former President Donald J. Trump’s most ambitious and hard-charging allies in Congress.

articles.headline: U.S. on Track to Add $19 Trillion in New Debt Over 10 Years
articles.snippet: Congressional Budget Office projections released on Wednesday suggested rising interest rates and bipartisan spending bills are adding to deficits.
articles.abstract: Congressional Budget Office projections released on Wednesday suggested rising interest rates and bipartisan spending bills are adding to deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is on track to add nearly $19 trillion to its national debt over the next decade, $3 trillion more than previously forecast, the result of rising costs for interest payments, veterans’ health care, retiree benefits and the military, the Congressional Budget Office said on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Financial Woes Thrust Lyft, Long in Uber’s Shadow, Into the Spotlight
articles.snippet: Lyft recovered from pandemic restrictions slower than Uber, and critics said it lacked the kind of ambitious investments that could distinguish itself from its rival.
articles.abstract: Lyft recovered from pandemic restrictions slower than Uber, and critics said it lacked the kind of ambitious investments that could distinguish itself from its rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2018, Lyft’s co-founders, Logan Green and John Zimmer, assembled employees in the cafeteria of the San Francisco company’s headquarters for a staff meeting. There, they explained that they were spending $250 million to purchase Motivate, the owner of the CitiBike bicycle-sharing program in New York.

articles.headline: In Ohio Town Where Train Derailed, Anxiety and Distrust Are Running Deep
articles.snippet: Nearly two weeks after a train carrying toxic chemicals derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, confusing messages from government officials have frayed locals’ trust.
articles.abstract: Nearly two weeks after a train carrying toxic chemicals derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, confusing messages from government officials have frayed locals’ trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: ‘The World’s Largest Construction Site’: The Race Is On to Rebuild Ukraine
articles.snippet: As the country’s leaders lay postwar plans, companies from around the world are jockeying for advantage in what could be a multibillion-dollar effort, although one loaded with risk.
articles.abstract: As the country’s leaders lay postwar plans, companies from around the world are jockeying for advantage in what could be a multibillion-dollar effort, although one loaded with risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Latvian roofing companies and South Korean trade specialists. Fuel cell manufacturers from Denmark and timber producers from Austria. Private equity titans from New York and concrete plant operators from Germany. Thousands of businesses around the globe are positioning themselves for a possible multibillion-dollar gold rush: the reconstruction of Ukraine once the war is over.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: The Retail C.E.O. Pipeline Is Running Dry
articles.snippet: The battered industry’s next generation of leaders needs a complex set of skills, yet scaled-down store training programs aren’t meeting demand.
articles.abstract: The battered industry’s next generation of leaders needs a complex set of skills, yet scaled-down store training programs aren’t meeting demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the hardest-to-find items in retail right now is a chief executive.

articles.headline: A Conversation With Bing’s Chatbot Left Me Deeply Unsettled
articles.snippet: A very strange conversation with the chatbot built into Microsoft’s search engine led to it declaring its love for me.
articles.abstract: A very strange conversation with the chatbot built into Microsoft’s search engine led to it declaring its love for me.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, after testing the new, A.I.-powered Bing search engine from Microsoft, I wrote that, much to my shock, it had replaced Google as my favorite search engine.

articles.headline: A New Goal for Abortion Bills: Punish or Protect Doctors
articles.snippet: The legislative calendar is packed with 300 abortion bills. “You can’t go to jail for screwing up an appendectomy,” one lawmaker said.
articles.abstract: The legislative calendar is packed with 300 abortion bills. “You can’t go to jail for screwing up an appendectomy,” one lawmaker said.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the fight over abortion access was kicked to the states after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, newly elected legislatures around the country are coming into session and are putting the polarizing issue at the top of their agendas. Around 300 bills in 40 states have been proposed so far — with a majority seeking to restrict access to abortion, and others trying to strengthen it.

articles.headline: Grand Jury in Georgia Trump Inquiry Sees Perjury by Witnesses, but No Vote Fraud
articles.snippet: Excerpts from the jury’s report, however, provided no indication of who, if anyone, jurors believed should be charged for interfering in Georgia’s 2020 election results.
articles.abstract: Excerpts from the jury’s report, however, provided no indication of who, if anyone, jurors believed should be charged for interfering in Georgia’s 2020 election results.
articles.lead_paragraph: A special grand jury that investigated election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies in Georgia said it saw possible evidence of perjury by “one or more” witnesses who testified before it, according to portions of the jury’s final report that were released on Thursday. The jurors also unanimously rebutted claims of widespread fraud made by Mr. Trump after the 2020 election.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: The PlayStation Goggles Are a Win for Gamers. Not for the Metaverse.
articles.snippet: Sony’s new $550 headset offers best-in-class virtual reality gaming, but it’s still hard to see why we need V.R. goggles at all.
articles.abstract: Sony’s new $550 headset offers best-in-class virtual reality gaming, but it’s still hard to see why we need V.R. goggles at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ah, the “metaverse.” Will a fantasy where our office meetings and social gatherings take place mostly in virtual reality ever come true?

articles.headline: Tesla Fired Buffalo Workers Seeking to Organize, Union Says
articles.snippet: A filing to the National Labor Relations Board called the dismissals retaliatory. The carmaker denied the allegation, saying they were based on performance.
articles.abstract: A filing to the National Labor Relations Board called the dismissals retaliatory. The carmaker denied the allegation, saying they were based on performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Barely 24 hours after a group of software workers at a Tesla factory in Buffalo issued a letter declaring their intention to unionize, firings began. And the organizers said it was not a coincidence.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: Behind China’s Balloons, a Push for Business to Serve the Military
articles.snippet: The Chinese government has tried to meld its military and civilian innovation, prompting a backlash from the United States.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government has tried to meld its military and civilian innovation, prompting a backlash from the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A People’s Liberation Army veteran turned drone manufacturer. A Shanghai real estate company that wagered there was more profit in high-altitude airships. An eminent Chinese aviation scientist who started more than a dozen companies to commercialize his expertise.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Chris Buckley
